{{wikipedia}}
{{also|Appendix:Variations of "us"}}
==English==

===Etymology 1===
From {{etyl|enm}} {{term|us|lang=enm}}, from {{etyl|ang}} {{term|us|ūs|pos=dative personal pronoun|us|lang=ang}}, from {{proto|Germanic|uns|us|lang=en}}, from {{proto|Indo-European|ne-||nō-||n-ge-||n-sme-|us|lang=en}}. Cognate with {{etyl|fry|-}} {{term|us|lang=fry}}, {{term|us|ús|us|lang=fry}}, {{etyl|nds|-}} {{term|us||us|lang=nds}}, {{etyl|nl|-}} {{term|ons||us|lang=nl}}, {{etyl|de|-}} {{term|uns||us|lang=de}}, {{etyl|da|-}} {{term|os||us|lang=da}}, {{etyl|la|-}} {{term|nos|nōs|we, us|lang=la}}.

====Pronunciation====
* {{qualifier|stressed}} {{enPR|ŭs}}, {{IPA|/ʌs/}}, {{SAMPA|/Vs/}}
* {{qualifier|unstressed}} {{IPA|/əs/}}, {{SAMPA|/@s/}}
* {{audio|en-us-us.ogg|Audio (US)}}
*: {{rhymes|ʌs}}

====Pronoun====
{{en-pron}}

# {{personal}} [[me]] and at least one other person; the objective case of '''[[we]]'''.
# {{colloquial}} [[me]]
#: ''Give '''us''' a look at your paper.''
#: ''Give '''us''' your fuckin' wallet!''

=====Quotations=====
* '''1611''' — [[w:King James Version of the Bible|King James Version of the Bible]], ''[[s:Bible (King James)/Luke|Luke]] 1:1''
*: Forasmuch as many have taken in hand to set forth in order a declaration of those things which are most surely believed among '''us'''...

=====Translations=====
{{trans-top|objective case of "we"}}
* [[American Sign Language]]: [[1^o-f@IpsiChest-FingerBack RoundHoriz 1^o-f@ContraChest-FingerBack]]
* Arabic: {{t-|ar|نا|alt=ـنا|tr=-naa}}
*: Egyptian Arabic: {{tø|arz|نا|alt=ـنا|tr=-naa|sc=Arab|xs=Egyptian Arabic}}
* Armenian: {{l|hy|մեզ|tr=mez}}
** Old Armenian: {{l|xcl|մեզ|tr=mez}}
* [[Bislama]]: [[yumi]], [[yumitupela]] (''dual inclusive''); [[yumitripela]] (''trial inclusive''); [[yumipela]] (''plural inclusive''); [[mitupela]] (''dual exclusive''); [[mitripela]] (''trial exclusive''); [[mipela]] (''plural exclusive'')
* [[Chamicuro]]: {{tø|ccc|a'ti}}
* Chinese:
*: Mandarin: {{t-|cmn|我們|sc=Hani}}, {{t-|cmn|我们|tr=wǒmen|sc=Hani}}
* Croatian: {{t+|hr|nas}}
* Dutch: {{t+|nl|ons}}
* Esperanto: {{t+|eo|nin|xs=Esperanto}}
* [[Ewe]]: [[míawo]]
* Finnish: {{t+|fi|meidät}},  {{t+|fi|meitä}}
* French: {{t+|fr|nous}}, à nous
* German: {{t+|de|uns}}
* Greek: {{t|el|μας|tr=mas}}
* [[Hopi]]: {{tø|hop|itamuy}}
* [[Ido]]: [[ni]]
* [[Interlingua]]: {{t|ia|nos}}
{{trans-mid}}
* Italian: {{t+|it|noi}}, a noi, {{t+|it|ci}}
* Japanese: wata (私達) ''[[or]]'' tachi (私達)
* Kazakh: {{t|kk|бізді|tr=bizdi|sc=Cyrl|xs=Kazakh}}
* Kurdish: {{ku-Arab|[[ئێمه‌]]}}
* Latin: {{qualifier|acc}} {{t+|la|nos}}, {{qualifier|dative}} {{t+|la|nobis}}, {{qualifier|ablative}} {{t+|la|nobis}}
* Malay: {{t+|ms|kita|xs=Malay}}
* [[Ngarrindjeri]]: {{tø|nay|ngatjagha}}
* [[Norn]]: [[vus]]
* Norwegian: {{t+|no|oss}}
* [[Old English]]: [[unc]] (dual), [[us#Old English|ūs/ūsiċ]] (plural)
* Polish: {{t-|pl|nas}}, {{t+|pl|nam}}, {{t-|pl|nami}}
* Portuguese: {{t+|pt|nos}}
* Romanian: [[ne]] (''unstressed dative and accusative''), [[nouă]] (''stressed dative''), ([[pe]]) [[noi]] (''stressed accusative'')
* Slovene: [[midva]] (‘us two’), [[midve]] (‘us two women’), [[mi]] (three or more), [[me]] (three or more women)
* Spanish: {{t+|es|nos}}, {{t+|es|nosotros}}, {{t-|es|nosotras}}
* Swedish: {{t+|sv|oss}}
* Ukrainian: {{t+|uk|нас|tr=nas|xs=Ukrainian}}
* [[Volapük]]: {{t|vo|obis}}
* Welsh: {{t-|cy|ni|xs=Welsh}}
* [[West Frisian]]: {{t+|fy|ús|xs=West Frisian}}
{{trans-bottom}}

{{trans-top|colloquial: me}}
* German: {{t+|de|uns}}
{{trans-mid}}
{{trans-bottom}}

=====See also=====
* [[we]]
* [[our]]
* [[ours]]
* [[ume]]

====Determiner====
{{en-det}}

# The speakers/writers, or the speaker/writer and at least one other person.
#: ''It's not good enough for '''us''' teachers.''

=====See also=====
* [[we]]

===Etymology 2===
Derived from the similarity between the letter [[u]] and the Greek letter [[µ]].

====Symbol====
'''us'''

# {{alternative spelling of|µs}}

====Statistics====
* {{rank|must|these|two|89|us|before|see|over}}

===Anagrams===
* [[SU#English|SU]], [[Su#English|Su]]

===Pronoun===
{{ca-ppron|type=procl+encl_con|encl=vos}}

# [[you]] (plural, direct or indirect object)
# {{contraction of|vos|lang=ca}}

====Declension====
{{ca-decl-ppron}}

----

==French==

===Etymology===
{{etyl|fro|fr}} {{term|us|lang=fro}} < {{etyl|la|fr}} {{term|usus|lang=la}}

===Noun===
{{infl|fr|noun|g=m|g2=p}}

# {{plurale tantum|lang=fr}} [[customs]]; [[traditions]]

====Usage notes====
only used in Modern French as ''us et coutumes'' (traditions and customs)

===Anagrams===
* [[su#French|su]]

----

==Latin==

===Pronunciation===
* {{audio|la-ecc-us.ogg|Audio}}

===Verb===
{{la-verb-form|us esse}}

# {{conjugation of|absto|abstō|perf|pass|inf|lang=la}}

----

==Old English==

===Etymology===
From {{proto|Germanic|lang=ang}} from {{proto|Indo-European|n̥s||nes|lang=ang}}. Cognates include Old Frisian {{term|us|ūs|lang=ofs}} (West Frisian {{term|us|ús|lang=fy}}), Old Saxon {{term|us|ūs|lang=osx}} (Dutch {{term|ons|lang=nl}}), Old High German {{term|uns|lang=goh}} (German {{term|uns|lang=de}}), Old Norse {{term|oss|lang=non}} (Swedish {{term|oss|lang=sv}}), Gothic {{term|𐌿𐌽𐍃|tr=uns|lang=got|sc=Goth}}.  The Indo-European root is also the source of Latin {{term|nos|lang=la}}.

===Pronunciation===
* {{IPA|/uːs/|lang=ang}}

===Pronoun===
{{infl|ang|pronoun|head=ūs|personal pronoun}}

# [[us#English|us]]: accusative or dative plural form of [[ic#Old English|iċ]]

----

==Old French==

===Etymology===
{{etyl|la|fro}} {{term|usus|lang=la}}

===Noun===
{{fro-noun|m|us|us|us}}

# [[tradition]] or [[custom]]

----

==Tz'utujil==

===Noun===
{{infl|tzj|noun}}

# [[fly]] (insect)

----

==Volapük==

===Adverb===
{{infl|vo|adverb}}

# [[there]]

----
